conclusion: To determine the height H above the ground at which the fire extinguishing projectile hits the high-rise building, we need to analyze the horizontal and vertical components of the projectile's motion.
The horizontal component of the initial velocity is given by v0x = v0 * cos(θ).
The horizontal distance L is covered in time t by the equation L = v0x * t.
Substituting v0x into the equation gives t = L / (v0 * cos(θ)).
Given v0 = 50 m/s, θ = 53°, and cos(53°) = 0.6.
Substituting the values, t = 60 m / (50 m/s * 0.6) = 60 m / 30 m/s = 2 s.
The vertical component of the initial velocity is given by v0y = v0 * sin(θ).
Substituting the values, v0y = 50 m/s * 0.8 = 40 m/s.
The vertical displacement H can be found using the equation H = v0y * t - (1/2) * g * t^2.
Given t = 2 s and g = 10 m/s².
Substituting the values, H = 40 m/s * 2 s - (1/2) * 10 m/s² * (2 s)^2.
Simplifying, H = 80 m - (1/2) * 10 m/s² * 4 s² = 80 m - 20 m = 60 m.
The height H above the ground at which the fire extinguishing projectile hits the high-rise building is 60 m.
